bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 13, 1876

div1.p: Reed has not heard from Emilie Lawrence. He tells her he misses her, and reports on cases of measles at the base.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 13, 1876
div1.opener:
C1
B9
Willet's Point, N.Y.H.
March 13th 76.
My darling Emilie;
div1.p:
I had ex-
pected to receive a darling
little letter from your sweet
self, this morning, but not-
withstanding all my expecta-
tions, no letter came- I tell
you, it is very hard to be
separated from one's Sweet-
heart for 10 days without
hearing so much as one
word- I want to hear from
you so much, my precious-
to know what you have been
doing since I left- whether
time has passed swiftly
or hung heavily on your
hands- whether your hours
have been happy & free from
care. These & much more I
would desire to know. Oh!
the blessed, happy hours spent
in Murfreesboro! These, indeed,
make the oasis in the desert
of my existence- I look back
upon them, & with a heart
full of gratitude, thank my
maker that He has vouched-
safe to me such golden
moments! So sweet & pre-
cious are they to my soul, that
I would ask no happier hours
in the great unknown Fu-
ture! To sit by your side,
to look into your dear face,
& talk with you, this is my
delight, for Emilie, darling,
I love you! And, oh! when
when you are mine, you
will not doubt that I love
you devotedly. Would you
believe me, did I tell you
that not a night has passed,
since my return, that I did
not dream of you, darling?
Most true it is- My thoughts
wander back to the dear,
little village & I see you
again as “in the flesh-”
Would to Heaven, that I may
dream of you, every day,
for the remainder of my
days! I believe I dreamed
that you had given me the
photograph which you
promised- Now, don't for-
get that, my darling, for I
am so anxious to have
a good photograph of you.
If Mr Grimes doesn't fulfil
his promise, I'll never forgive
him- I did not tell you that
I found Dr Heger sick, on my
return- Yes, confined to his
bed- How fortunate that I
returned just in time to attend
to several very urgent cases-
we are in the midst of the
measles & I have all I can
do -- about 35 patients to see
morning & evening- I receive
much sympathy from all
hands, who think that I am
very hard worked- I find time,
however, to study a French
lesson, every day- am going
along slowly, but learning as
I go. Has my little darling com-
menced her piano practice? Of
course she has- will write on
Thursday.
div1.closer:
As ever, your fond &
devoted Walter.
